name: Protection Shield with Airbnb Reframe
description: A compact trust module for listing pages that visually articulates the 3-layer protection model using shield iconography and an embedded Airbnb reframing comparison. Resolves the #1 guest objection ('I can't see it before signing') without requiring an agent call. Each protection layer is shown as a step with a checkmark, and the reframe comparison sits below in a subtle tinted container.
compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1000-006 (Patient Follow-Up Email) by embedding the agent trust bridge INTO the listing page rather than only in email. Borrows the match-quality visual confidence from ds-ui-1001-002 (Listing Match Quality Card) but applies it to protection guarantees instead of schedule matching. Uses the timeline-node pattern from ds-ui-1000-004 (Between-Stay Status Display) to show the 3-step protection sequence.
fills_gap: Cross-journey elements — this element shows the guest what the HOST also sees (both parties are protected), creating transparency across the host-guest boundary.
html_css:
You're Protected
3-layer guarantee on every booking
No obligation until you sign
Browse, propose, negotiate — you only commit when you're ready.
24-hour satisfaction guarantee
Spend your first night. If anything doesn't match the listing, get a full refund.
Payment held by Split Lease
Your money stays with us until you confirm. Security deposit protected too.
How it compares
On Airbnb, you book without touring first. With Split Lease, you get the same convenience plus 24 hours and a full refund if anything is off.
The host sees these same protections — both sides are covered
behavioral_notes: Auto-expands on first listing page visit. Collapses to header-only on subsequent visits with an expand toggle. The reframe comparison box is the key persuasive element — it must be visible without scrolling on mobile. The 'host sees' line at the bottom is the cross-journey element that fills a library gap.
emotional_intent: Transform anxiety ('I'm signing blind') into confidence ('I'm better protected here than on Airbnb'). The shield icon and gradient convey institutional strength; the reframing text conveys conversational warmth.
test_criteria: Post-proposal survey: 80%+ of guests who saw the shield module should mention the 24-hour guarantee or refund unprompted when asked 'What would you do if the apartment didn't match?'

name: Matching Pipeline Status Tracker
description: A horizontal pipeline visualization showing the guest's proposal journey from submission to host introduction. Each stage is a connected node with completion status, current-stage animation, and estimated timeline. Designed to fill the 2-3 week silence gap after bid submission. Shows the named agent and partial match results as they emerge.
compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1000-004 (Between-Stay Status Display) from a vertical timeline into a horizontal pipeline for a different context (pre-lease matching vs. active-lease stays). Borrows the persistent profile-strip pattern from ds-ui-1001-006 (Guest Requirements Profile Strip) — the tracker is similarly persistent and follows the guest across pages. Uses the status-first architecture from ds-ui-1000-003 (Status-First Host Dashboard) applied to the guest's negotiation phase.
fills_gap: Messaging/communication UI — the tracker includes an agent message area where the named agent can communicate status updates, serving as a lightweight messaging channel without building a full chat system.

behavioral_notes: Pipeline nodes animate left-to-right as stages complete. Current stage pulses subtly. Agent messages arrive as push notifications and appear in the tracker. Partial match previews are blurred/minimal until the agent confirms compatibility. The 'next matching batch' line sets explicit timeline expectations.
emotional_intent: Transform the anxiety of silence ('Is anything happening?') into the calm of visibility ('Robert is working on it and I can see progress'). The named agent with avatar creates the concierge feeling Theodore responded to.
test_criteria: Post-bid retention: 80%+ of guests should open the tracker at least once per week during the 2-3 week matching period. Agent call volume for 'what's happening with my bid?' should decrease by 30%.

name: Weekly Savings Value Tracker
description: A persistent dashboard module on the guest Stays Manager that shows cumulative savings from the discount tier, this week's contribution, and an Airbnb comparison. After each Space Care photo submission, the savings counter animates to show the concrete dollar impact. Transforms the cleaning obligation into visible financial reward.
compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-005 (Space Care Photo Upload with Streak Counter) by adding the FINANCIAL dimension that the streak alone doesn't capture. Borrows the stay stats pattern from ds-ui-1001-004 (This-Week Stay Card) — both show guest achievement metrics at a glance. Extends ds-ui-1001-003 (Price Decomposition) from a pre-lease pricing tool to an active-lease value tracker, showing how day-rate savings accumulate over time.
fills_gap: Review/rating UI — the savings tracker includes a micro-review prompt ('How was this week's stay? Quick tap') that appears after the savings animation, capturing guest sentiment at the moment of highest satisfaction (just saw their savings). This is the first micro-review element in the library.

behavioral_notes: Savings counter animates (odometer roll) after each Space Care submission. The comparison section uses strikethrough on the Airbnb price to make the savings feel tangible. The micro-review appears only after the savings reveal — timing it at the moment of peak satisfaction. 'Smart Stay Tier' replaces 'Discount Tier' per the emotional framing principle.
emotional_intent: Transform weekly cleaning from obligation to achievement. The big savings number says 'your effort is paying off.' The Airbnb comparison says 'you made the smart choice.' The micro-review says 'your experience matters and your host cares.'
test_criteria: Cleaning submission rate for discount-tier guests increases 15%+ when savings tracker is visible. Micro-review completion rate above 40% (one tap, no friction). Cumulative savings milestone messages ('enough for an extra week!') should be recalled by 60%+ of guests in exit surveys.

name: Move-In Digital House Manual
description: A mobile-optimized digital house manual that replaces physical welcome packets and scattered PDF documents. Organized into scannable sections (check-in, WiFi, house rules, neighborhood, emergency) with one-tap access to the most urgent info. Accessible from the active lease card on the Stays Manager. Includes a first-visit checklist that transforms into a reference guide after the first stay.
compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-004 (This-Week Stay Card with Check-In) by extending what happens AFTER check-in — the house manual is the next thing the guest needs. Borrows the chip/toggle selection pattern from ds-ui-1000-005 (Guest Preference Quick-Set Panel) for section navigation. Uses the day-chip visual language from ds-ui-1001-001 (Day-of-Week Flexibility Selector) as a familiar interaction pattern for navigating manual sections.
fills_gap: House manual / move-in checklist — this is the first guest onboarding element for arrival in the library. No existing elements cover the physical-to-digital transition at move-in.

behavioral_notes: Checklist items are interactive — tap to mark as done. On first visit, items appear as a to-do list. After all items are checked, the section transforms into a reference guide (checkmarks remain, items become collapsible). WiFi password has a one-tap copy button. Emergency info is always visible with high-contrast red accent. The 'Message' button in the header fills the messaging gap.
emotional_intent: Transform the anxiety of arriving at a stranger's space into the confidence of having a guide. The gradient header and host contact create warmth. The checklist creates structure. The WiFi card and emergency bar provide immediate practical value. The overall feeling should be: 'I know exactly what to do.'
test_criteria: First-stay completion of all checklist items: 70%+. WiFi copy button usage: 80%+ on first visit. Emergency info awareness: 90%+ of guests should know where to find emergency contacts when surveyed after move-in.

name: Guest Notification Center with Escalation Tiers
description: A notification center designed specifically for the guest side, with three escalation tiers: Ambient (activity feed), Attention (action needed), and Urgent (time-sensitive). Currently notification escalation exists only for hosts. This fills the guest notification gap by providing structured, non-overwhelming notification management tied to the guest's specific journey context.
compounds_on_explanation: Borrows the action-card pattern from ds-ui-1000-003 (Status-First Host Dashboard) where action items have a purple left-border accent. Extends the urgency model from ds-ui-1001-007 (Date Exception Quick-Modify Panel) where time-sensitive changes need immediate attention. Uses the timeline dot system from ds-ui-1000-004 (Between-Stay Status Display) for the ambient activity feed.
fills_gap: Guest-side notifications — notification escalation exists for hosts only. This element provides the guest equivalent with three tiers matched to guest-specific actions.

behavioral_notes: Three tiers filter automatically based on action type and deadline. Urgent: time-bound actions with consequences. Attention: actions needed but no deadline pressure. Ambient: informational feed. Badge count on the nav reflects only Urgent + Attention items. Ambient items appear read/unread but don't contribute to the badge. Jessica's note in the ambient feed fills the messaging gap without building a full chat system.
emotional_intent: Reduce the anxiety of 'did I miss something?' while avoiding notification fatigue. The three-tier system lets the guest quickly assess: 'Do I need to act NOW (urgent), SOON (attention), or just know about it (ambient)?' The purple accent on attention items connects to the brand without alarming; the red accent on urgent items demands action.
test_criteria: Notification engagement rate: 90%+ of Urgent notifications should be acted on within 48 hours. Attention notifications within 1 week. Ambient feed should be opened at least once per week by 60%+ of active guests.

name: Calendar Week View with Stay Schedule
description: A compact calendar week view that shows the guest's stay schedule in the context of actual dates, not just abstract day-badge chips. Each day cell shows stay status (your night, host's night, available), pricing, and any exceptions. Bridges the gap between the abstract day-badge pattern and real calendar planning. This is the first calendar view in the library — all previous elements are card-based.
compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-001 (Day-of-Week Flexibility Selector) from abstract day selection into calendar-grounded date awareness. Borrows the exception-week modification pattern from ds-ui-1001-007 (Date Exception Quick-Modify Panel) and embeds it directly into the calendar view. Uses the price-per-day concept from ds-ui-1001-003 (Price Decomposition with Day-Rate Bars) but shows it in calendar context rather than bar charts.
fills_gap: Calendar/scheduling views — everything in the library is card-based. This is the first calendar element, providing temporal context that day-badge chips alone cannot.

behavioral_notes: Tap any day to open the date exception modifier (from ds-ui-1001-007 pattern). Your-night days show per-night pricing. Exception days use dashed red outline and strikethrough. The month-view toggle switches between week and month views. Today indicator (purple dot) orients the guest in time. Calendar syncs with the day-badge pattern — same color coding (purple = your night, gray = host's night).
emotional_intent: Ground the abstract split-schedule concept in real dates. Day-badge chips say 'you stay Friday-Sunday.' The calendar says 'THIS Friday March 6, you check in at Jessica's.' test_criteria: Calendar view engagement: 50%+ of active-lease guests should view the calendar at least once per month. Date exception creation rate should be higher from the calendar than from the standalone date exception panel (hypothesis: visual context makes exceptions feel less risky).

name: Host-Guest Perspective Bridge Card
description: A card that shows the guest what the host sees about them — their space care streak, reliability score, and review summary — creating transparency across the host-guest boundary. This is the first cross-journey element in the library: it reveals one user's view of another, building mutual accountability and trust. After completing Space Care, the guest sees: 'Here's what Jessica sees about you.'
compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-005 (Space Care Streak Counter) by showing where that streak DATA goes — the host sees it. Borrows the compatibility-badge visual language from ds-ui-1000-002 (Guest Proposal Card) — but reversed: instead of the host seeing guest attributes, the guest sees their own profile as the host perceives it. Uses the stay-stats pattern from ds-ui-1001-004 (This-Week Stay Card) as the data source for the perspective bridge.
fills_gap: Cross-journey elements — host seeing guest's perspective, or vice versa. This is the first element that explicitly bridges the two journey types, showing one party what the other party sees.

behavioral_notes: Appears after Space Care submission (optimally) or accessible from the Stays Manager at any time. The host's actual note is shown only if the host has written one — otherwise a fallback message: 'Jessica hasn't left a note yet — but your stats speak for themselves.' The profile stats are real-time and accumulate across leases. The cross-journey bridge creates mutual accountability: the guest sees what the host sees, motivating continued good behavior.
emotional_intent: Create pride and ownership in the guest's reputation. Seeing '9/9 Space Care' and 'Perfect streak' from the HOST's perspective is more powerful than seeing it from your own dashboard. The host's personal note adds emotional warmth. The overall feeling: 'I'm building a reputation that matters — this host sees me as a great guest.'
test_criteria: Engagement: 60%+ of guests should view the perspective bridge at least once per lease. Behavioral impact: guests who view the bridge should have 10%+ higher Space Care submission rate than those who don't. Emotional impact: post-lease survey question 'Did you feel like a valued guest?' should score 4.2/5.0 or higher.
